title: 107_hr2645
content: The "Motor Donor Act" establishes a National Organ Donor Registry under the Public Health Service Act. The purposes of this subpart are to increase organ and tissue donor registrations, enhance information on donation, ensure accurate information on donation wishes, and provide grants for state donor registries. Definitions are provided in this subpart. The Secretary will establish a national organ and tissue donor registry, containing information of individuals who have expressed intent to be donors. The Motor Donor Act establishes a national registry for organ and tissue donors, including individuals' personal information and a unique identification number. The Secretary will coordinate with states and organ procurement organizations to share data and provide links to the registry. The Motor Donor Act establishes a national registry for organ and tissue donors. The Secretary will coordinate with states and organ procurement organizations to share data and provide access to the registry 24/7. The Motor Donor Act establishes a national registry for organ and tissue donors. The Secretary will disseminate a pamphlet to US citizens with information on organ donations and a website address for registry participation. The Motor Donor Act establishes a national registry for organ and tissue donors. Individuals can elect to participate in the Registry through a website address provided. Within 4 months of registration, the Secretary will notify individuals about their participation. Participation in the Registry does not affect organ or tissue allocation. The Registry serves as a registry of an individual's intent to serve as an organ donor. The Motor Donor Act establishes a national registry for organ and tissue donors. Participation in the Registry signifies an individual's intent to serve as a donor, not legally binding consent. Participants have the right to cancel at any time, with the Secretary promptly removing their information. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to states for this purpose. The Secretary can award grants to States for establishing State registries linked to the Motor Donor Act. States must submit applications demonstrating their procedures for individual participation. The State must establish procedures for individuals to make legally binding organ and tissue donation gifts when applying for a driver's license. The application must assure compliance with specific requirements, including incorporating the donation process into driver's license applications. The State motor vehicle authority application allows individuals to designate their intent to be an organ and tissue donor. The application must include a question about organ donor designation in the State registry or on the driver's license. The State agency process allows individuals to indicate their organ donor preference on their driver's license. Only those who answer affirmatively will have their preference noted in the State registry or on their license. The State will forward the names of affirmative responders to the Registry. The State procedures require forwarding information of individuals who choose to be organ donors to the Registry within 100 days of designation. Those who do not wish to be donors will not have their names forwarded. The State procedures mandate forwarding donor information to the Registry within 100 days. Individuals who opt out of being donors will not have their details forwarded. Access to donor information is provided to organ procurement organizations 24/7 without any fees. The Secretary gives priority to this process. The Secretary prioritizes grants for states collaborating with organ procurement organizations. Grants awarded to a state cannot exceed $300,000. An advisory task force on organ and tissue donation, consisting of 5 members appointed by the Secretary, is established. The Task Force consists of 5 members appointed by the Secretary based on their experience with organ donations, transplants, or procurement. At least 1 member must be a physician with transplant experience, and another member must have procurement experience. The Task Force consists of 5 members appointed by the Secretary based on their experience with organ donations, transplants, or procurement. At least 1 member must be a physician with transplant experience, and another member must have procurement experience. Each member serves a 3-year term, with staggered terms for initial members, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Task Force's functions include overseeing organ transplants. The Task Force, appointed by the Secretary, shall not affect its powers and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Task Force will partner with the Coalition on Donation to enhance the national awareness campaign for the Registry and submit a report with recommendations for improving the Registry within a year of the Motor Donor Act's enactment. The Task Force, appointed by the Secretary, will submit a report with recommendations for improving the Registry, increasing public awareness about organ and tissue donation, and enhancing the donation process. Members will not receive compensation but will be reimbursed for travel expenses. The Task Force, appointed by the Secretary, may accept voluntary and uncompensated services of members while away from their regular places of business. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Task Force without reimbursement, with administrative support provided by the Department of Health and Human Services. Authorization of Appropriations for the Task Force includes funding for registry, grants, and an awareness campaign from 2002 to 2006. The Task Force is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Task Force is authorized to receive $3,000,000 annually from 2002 to 2006 for subsection (h)(3) activities, with funds remaining available until expended. SEC. 3. AMENDMENT OF INTERNAL REVENUE CODE. Subpart 2--Organ Procurement. Section 6103(m) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow disclosure of taxpayer information to the Department of Health and Human Services for organ donor program purposes. Officers and employees of the Department of Health and Human Services can use subparagraph (A) for contacting individuals about the national organ and tissue donor registry under section 370(c) of the Public Health Service Act. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Subpart 2 of part H of title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended in sections 374(a), 374(d), 375(1), and 378, by replacing "this part" with "this subpart".
